content:
Just got this clash, it was fun, although it quickly got surprisingly messy as I started with the very short

h,m = map(int,input().split())
h = 23 - h; m = 60 - m
h += m//60; m %= 60
print(f'{h:02}:{m:02}')

and then iteratively added many if and else to account for all the special cases, like if m has only one digit instead of two, or if m is greater than 60, or if there is no period in the input.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Ce puzzle convient pour un CoC en mode reverse

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: ✅ Good job ;)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good reverse
I changed stub, input is typed as string to prevent coder being stuck in the idea that it is a regular float.
The inputs aren't in the decimal system, but a strange ambiguous (1.1 == 0.7) mixture of the decimal and sexagesimal (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexagesimal) systems.

Goal
* Please fix the typo: Fortunatly => Fortunately.

Constraints
* Please change "int" to "integer".

* Please change "decimals" to "decimal part".

General
* I don't quite understand your calculation. For example, 0.3 hour = 0.3 x 60 minutes = 18 minutes. So 4.3 hours till midnight would be 24:00 - 04:18 = 19:42. But your answer is 19:30 (Test 3). Have I misunderstood anything?

Thanks.

First, it's a good clash of code.

However, I think you should add an example when you say 'decimals have already been converted into minutes'. It would be clearer because I didn't quite understand what you meant. I had a solution where the decimal corresponded to a percentage of 60 min, which of course didn't work. I realized my mistake thanks to the validators which helped me understand what you meant with this sentence.

It could be something like '0.3 means 30 minutes' because 0.3 could be 3min or 300 min, this is not obvious when you say 'converted'. 

Plus, it would be great to add a validator with an entry that has a decimal equal to 6 like 2.6.

Thanks for your review!
My first idea was to create a "reverse" clash, so every tests are directly displayed. But as I don't know if choosing that mode means it will always be played in reverse I wrote a short description and use the constraints 0 < decimals of number < 100 as hint. It's important that the input looks like a float so I don't want to have "4.30". I agree, an example with minutes could help, or an explanation in description. I will change it a bit.

Thanks for your review!
I made the changes.
And some others: example shown is now the previous Test 3 and I have simplified the explanation in description. Maybe it's not enough.
Your mistake is intended, that's the tricky part of the puzzle.
The input is a string that may look like a float or an integer. But it's a time: 4.3 can be written as 04:30, till midnight it gives you the answer as 19:30.
But as it looks like a float, and that clock is silly, it can be 4.7, and must be understand as 05:10, till midnight it gives 18:50
Tell me what you think about it.
And, please, can you tell me, I check "without statement" in game modes, does it mean it can be a reverse clash or it will always be?
Exactly!
Thank you!
Thanks!
merci

Same! Took me 10 minutes to solve this way. Very tough reverse clash.

I'm the only person who really solved it in my clash, but user @Etherri cheated with AI-generated code in 1m16s (24 lines of fully commented code with long variable names, lol, dead giveaway).

I'm afraid I can't understand your explanation. I think it's better to provide more explanation in Goal section.

I'm not sure if I get your question. Reverse mode will be shown properly without a statement only during a clash. There isn't a way to show a clash in Reverse mode in this contribution view.

If this is not what you're asking about, please let me know.

About the tricky part:
Consider the input as a time with blanks to fill with "0": "4.3" => "04.30"
replace "." by ":": "04.30" => "04:30"
till midnight: "19:30"
That was my first idea.
While coding my solution I thought that this fake float can have decimals greater than 0.59. So I wrote Test 5: "14.7" => "14:70" => "15:10" => "08:50"
I wanted to create a Reverse clash, where every Tests are directly displayed, with Test 7 being "23.59" => "00:01" I think it gives a huge hint on what to do with that input. And it invites coder to be attentive to every tests provided (no disrespect intended).

Now about my question: as I wrote above, I wanted to create a Reverse puzzle, so I checked the appropriate game mode. But I don't know if doing so means this puzzle will always be a Reverse puzzle or if it means it just can be a Reverse puzzle. Maybe, to be sure it will be set as Reverse I have to uncheck "Speed" mode.

I hope my puzzle and my question are clearer now. Thanks in advance.

Now I kind of understand your rules. You have to spell them all out in Goal section if you want the clash to be played in modes other than Reverse mode.

Regarding the other question: If you enable Reverse mode only, the clash will always be played in Reverse mode only. If you enable other modes as well, the clash will be played in a mode randomly selected from the enabled modes.

Hope this helps.

This helps a lot, I turn off Speed mode, only Reverse.
I named my tests, that could help, but I can't remember if player can see these names in Reverse mode.
But still, I think Test 7 "Happy new day!", is quite self explanatory.
No, players cannot see anything except the visible tests (and inputs only, not even the names of the cases) and what you have written in the stub generator.
Indeed, it makes more sense if it is for a reverse mode.
